column1: Querying k-truss community in large and dynamic graphs,Xin Huang

column8: which brings nice structural andcomputational properties. We design a compact and elegant index structure which supportsthe efficient search of k-truss communities with a linear cost with respect to the communitysize. In addition
column9: we investigate the k-truss community search problem in a dynamic graphsetting with frequent insertions and deletions of graph vertices and edges. Extensiveexperiments on large real-world networks demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of …,Proceedings of the 2014 ACM SIGMOD international conference on Management of data,2014,72

column1: Robust reputation-based ranking on bipartite rating networks,Rong-Hua Li
column4: Hong Cheng,Abstract With the growth of the Internet and E-commerce
column5: bipartite rating networks areubiquitous. In such bipartite rating networks
column6: there exist two types of entities: the users andthe objects
column7: where users give ratings to objects. A fundamental problem in such networks ishow to rank the objects by user's ratings. Although it has been extensively studied in the pastdecade
column8: the existing algorithms either cannot guarantee convergence
column9: or are not robust tothe spammers. In this paper
column10: we propose six new reputation-based algorithms
column11: where theusers' reputation is determined by the aggregated difference between the users' ratings andthe corresponding objects' rankings. We prove that all of our algorithms converge into aunique fixed point. The time and space complexity of our algorithms are linear wrt the size ofthe graph
column12: thus they can be scalable to large datasets. Moreover
